summary: This is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel discussing the autopsy report of Jeffrey Epstein from the Office of Chief Medical Examiner (OCME). It details the office's request for redactions before the report is released to Epstein's brother, Mark Epstein, citing an ongoing criminal investigation and the sensitivity of included materials like draft FBI 302s and guard names.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.role: Next of kin of Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: He is Jeffrey Epstein's brother who has requested the autopsy report from OCME. The document discusses redacting sensitive information before releasing the report to him.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the autopsy report. His death by suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) is the focus of the ongoing investigation discussed.

connections.description: Mark Epstein is identified as Jeffrey Epstein's brother and next of kin, who is requesting the autopsy report.
Lt was on duty at the MCC at the time Jeffrey Epstein's body was found and was interviewed as a key witness by the FBI.

events.title: Planned submission of redactions to OCME
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office plans to provide their proposed redactions for the Epstein autopsy report to the Office of Chief Medical Examiner (OCME).

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The OCME autopsy concluded the cause was suicide.

keyFacts: The Office of Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) completed a full autopsy report on Jeffrey Epstein, concluding suicide, and included investigative materials like a draft FBI 302 interview of a key MCC witness.

The U.S. Attorney's Office requested OCME to redact sensitive materials (including names of prison guards under investigation, witness statements, and MCC documents) before releasing the report to Epstein's brother, Mark Epstein, to protect the ongoing criminal investigation.

A handwritten note found in Epstein's cell was referenced in the report; it was described as a list of grievances about MCC conditions (food, showers, bugs) and was assessed by OCME and investigators as not being a suicide note.
The U.S. Attorney's Office indicated the redaction request might not be permanent and could be revisited after a charging decision is made in the investigation.
